with Madrid in Morocco, and becoming the joint-top assist provider of the competition alongside <a href="/wiki/Toni_Kroos" title="Toni Kroos">Toni Kroos</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">&#91;187&#93;</a></sup> Ronaldo received a second successive <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_Ballon_d%27Or" title="2014 FIFA Ballon d&#39;Or">FIFA Ballon d'Or</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">&#91;188&#93;</a></sup> joining <a href="/wiki/Johan_Cruyff" title="Johan Cruyff">Johan Cruyff</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michel_Platini" title="Michel Platini">Michel Platini</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Marco_van_Basten" title="Marco van Basten">Marco van Basten</a> as a three-time Ballon d'Or winner.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">&#91;189&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="2015.E2.80.932017:_All-time_Real_Madrid_top_scorer_and_La_Und.C3.A9cima"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2015–2017:_All-time_Real_Madrid_top_scorer_and_La_Undécima">2015–2017: All-time Real Madrid top scorer and <i>La Undécima</i></span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ronaldo_vs._FC_Schalke_04_(16854146922).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Ronaldo_vs._FC_Schalke_04_%2816854146922%29.jpg/170px-Ronaldo_vs._FC_Schalke_04_%2816854146922%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="241" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Ronaldo_vs._FC_Schalke_04_%2816854146922%29.jpg/255px-Ronaldo_vs._FC_Schalke_04_%2816854146922%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Ronaldo_vs._FC_Schalke_04_%2816854146922%29.jpg/340px-Ronaldo_vs._FC_Schalke_04_%2816854146922%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2792" data-file-height="3963" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ronaldo_vs._FC_Schalke_04_(16854146922).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ronaldo scored a personal best of 61 goals in all competitions during the <a href="/wiki/2014%E2%80%9315_Real_Madrid_CF_season" title="2014–15 Real Madrid CF season">2014–15</a> season.</div></div></div>
<p>Madrid finished in second-place in La Liga in the 2014–15 season and exited at the semi-final stage in the Champions League.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">&#91;190&#93;</a></sup> In the latter competition, Ronaldo extended his run of scoring away to a record 12 matches with his strike in a 2–0 win against Schalke 04.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">&#91;191&#93;</a></sup> He scored both of his side's goals in the semi-finals against <a href="/wiki/Juventus_F.C." title="Juventus F.C.">Juventus</a>, where Madrid were eliminated 2–3 on aggregate.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">&#91;192&#93;</a></sup> With 10 goals, he finished the campaign as top scorer for a third consecutive season, alongside Messi and <a href="/wiki/Neymar" title="Neymar">Neymar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">&#91;193&#93;</a></sup> In La Liga, for the first time in his career he scored five goals in one game, including an eight-minute hat-trick, in a 9–1 rout of <a href="/wiki/Granada_CF" title="Granada CF">Granada</a> on 5 April.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">&#91;194&#93;</a></sup> His 300th goal for his club followed three days later in a 2–0 win against Rayo Vallecano.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">&#91;195&#93;</a></sup> Subsequent hat-tricks against Sevilla, <a href="/wiki/RCD_Espanyol" title="RCD Espanyol">Espanyol</a>, and Getafe took his number of hat-tricks for Real Madrid to 31, surpassing Di Stéfano's club record of 28.<sup id="cite_ref-AS_187-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AS-187">&#91;184&#93;</a></sup> He finished the season with 48 goals, winning a second consecutive Pichichi and the European Golden Shoe for a record fourth time.<sup id="cite_ref-AS_187-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AS-187">&#91;184&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>At the start of his seventh season at Real Madrid, the <a href="/wiki/2015%E2%80%9316_La_Liga" title="2015–16 La Liga">2015–16 campaign</a>, Ronaldo became the club's <a href="/wiki/List_of_Real_Madrid_CF_records_and_statistics#Goalscorers" title="List of Real Madrid CF records and statistics">all-time top scorer</a>, first in the league and then in all competitions. His five-goal haul in a 6–0 away win over Espanyol on 12 September took his tally in La Liga to 230 goals in 203 games, surpassing the club's previous recordholder, Raúl.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">&#91;196&#93;</a></sup> A month later, on 17 October, he again surpassed Raúl when he scored the second goal in a 3–0 defeat of Levante at the Bernabéu to take his overall total for the club to 324 goals.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">&#91;note 4&#93;</a></sup> Ronaldo also became the <a href="/wiki/List_of_European_Cup_and_UEFA_Champions_League_top_scorers" class="mw-redirect" title="List of European Cup and UEFA Champions League top scorers">all-time top scorer in the Champions League</a> with a hat-trick in the first group match against <a href="/wiki/FC_Shakhtar_Donetsk" title="FC Shakhtar Donetsk">Shakhtar Donetsk</a>, having finished the previous season level with Messi on 77 goals.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">&#91;198&#93;</a></sup> Two goals against Malmö FF in a 2–0 away win on 30 September saw him reach the milestone of 500 career goals for both club and country.<sup id="cite_ref-500_goals_203-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-500_goals-203">&#91;199&#93;</a></sup> He subsequently became the first player to score double figures in the competition's group stage, setting the record at 11 goals, including another four-goal haul against Malmö.<sup id="cite_ref-UEFA_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UEFA-204">&#91;200&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:257px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo_ante_el_Celta_de_Vigo.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Cristiano_Ronaldo_ante_el_Celta_de_Vigo.JPG/255px-Cristiano_Ronaldo_ante_el_Celta_de_Vigo.JPG" decoding="async" width="255" height="174" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Cristiano_Ronaldo_ante_el_Celta_de_Vigo.JPG/383px-Cristiano_Ronaldo_ante_el_Celta_de_Vigo.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Cristiano_Ronaldo_ante_el_Celta_de_Vigo.JPG/510px-Cristiano_Ronaldo_ante_el_Celta_de_Vigo.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4577" data-file-height="3123" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo_ante_el_Celta_de_Vigo.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>By March 2016, Ronaldo had scored 252 goals in 228 matches in La Liga to become the competition's second-<a href="/wiki/Football_records_and_statistics_in_Spain#Top_30_goalscorers,_all-time" title="Football records and statistics in Spain">highest goalscorer</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Ronaldo's four goals in a 7–1 home win over Celta de Vigo on 5 March 2016 took his total to 252 goals in La Liga, becoming the competition's second-highest scorer in history behind Messi.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">&#91;201&#93;</a></sup> He scored a hat-trick against <a href="/wiki/VfL_Wolfsburg" title="VfL Wolfsburg">VfL Wolfsburg</a> to send his club into the Champions League semi-finals.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">&#91;202&#93;</a></sup> The treble took his tally in the competition to 16 goals, making him the top scorer for the fourth consecutive season, and the fifth overall.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">&#91;203&#93;</a></sup> Suffering apparent fitness issues, Ronaldo gave a poorly-received performance in the <a href="/wiki/2016_UEFA_Champions_League_Final" title="2016 UEFA Champions League Final">final</a> against Atlético Madrid, in a repeat of the 2014 final, though his penalty in the subsequent shoot-out secured <i>La Undécima</i>, Madrid's 11th victory.<sup id="cite_ref-Independent16_208-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Independent16-208">&#91;204&#93;</a></sup> For the sixth successive year, he ended the season having scored more than 50 goals across all competitions.<sup id="cite_ref-Independent16_208-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Independent16-208">&#91;204&#93;</a></sup> For his efforts during the season, he received the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Best_Player_in_Europe_Award" class="mw-redirect" title="UEFA Best Player in Europe Award">UEFA Best Player in Europe Award</a> for a second time.<sup id="cite_ref-bestplayerineurope_209-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bestplayerineurope-209">&#91;205&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Ronaldo missed Real Madrid's first three matches of the <a href="/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_La_Liga" title="2016–17 La Liga">2016–17 season</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/2016_UEFA_Super_Cup" title="2016 UEFA Super Cup">2016 UEFA Super Cup</a> against Sevilla, as he continued to rehabilitate the knee injury he suffered against <a href="/wiki/France_national_football_team" title="France national football team">France</a> in the final of <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016_Final" title="UEFA Euro 2016 Final">Euro 2016</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">&#91;206&#93;</a></sup> On 15 September, he did not celebrate his late free kick equaliser against <a href="/wiki/Sporting_CP" title="Sporting CP">Sporting CP</a> in the Champions League, with Ronaldo stating post match, "they made me who I am."<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">&#91;207&#93;</a></sup> On 7 November, his contract was updated for the second time and extended by three years to 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">&#91;208&#93;</a></sup> On 19 November, he scored a hat-trick in a 3–0 away win against Atlético Madrid, making him the all-time top scorer in the <a href="/wiki/Madrid_derby" class="mw-redirect" title="Madrid derby">Madrid derby</a> with 18 goals.<sup id="cite_ref-madrid_derby_top_scorer_213-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-madrid_derby_top_scorer-213">&#91;209&#93;</a></sup> On 15 December, Ronaldo scored his 500th club career goal in the 2–0 victory over <a href="/wiki/Club_Am%C3%A9rica" title="Club América">Club América</a> in the semi-finals of the <a href="/wiki/2016_FIFA_Club_World_Cup" title="2016 FIFA Club World Cup">FIFA Club World Cup</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">&#91;210&#93;</a></sup> He then scored a hat-trick in the 4–2 win over Japanese club <a href="/wiki/Kashima_Antlers" title="Kashima Antlers">Kashima Antlers</a> in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">&#91;211&#93;</a></sup> Ronaldo finished the tournament as top scorer with four goals and was also named player of the tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">&#91;212&#93;</a></sup> He won the <a href="/wiki/2016_Ballon_d%27Or" title="2016 Ballon d&#39;Or">Ballon d'Or</a> for a fourth time and the inaugural <a href="/wiki/The_Best_FIFA_Football_Awards_2016" title="The Best FIFA Football Awards 2016">Best FIFA Men's Player</a>, a revival of the former <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Player_of_the_Year" title="FIFA World Player of the Year">FIFA World Player of the Year</a>, largely owing to his success with Portugal in winning Euro 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">&#91;213&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="2017.E2.80.932018:_Fifth_Champions_League_title_and_fifth_Ballon_d.27Or"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2017–2018:_Fifth_Champions_League_title_and_fifth_Ballon_d'Or">2017–2018: Fifth Champions League title and fifth Ballon d'Or</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Real_Madrid,_campe%C3%B3n_de_la_Champions_(27309388231).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Real_Madrid%2C_campe%C3%B3n_de_la_Champions_%2827309388231%29.jpg/260px-Real_Madrid%2C_campe%C3%B3n_de_la_Champions_%2827309388231%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="167" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Real_Madrid%2C_campe%C3%B3n_de_la_Champions_%2827309388231%29.jpg/390px-Real_Madrid%2C_campe%C3%B3n_de_la_Champions_%2827309388231%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Real_Madrid%2C_campe%C3%B3n_de_la_Champions_%2827309388231%29.jpg/520px-Real_Madrid%2C_campe%C3%B3n_de_la_Champions_%2827309388231%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4441" data-file-height="2859" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Real_Madrid,_campe%C3%B3n_de_la_Champions_(27309388231).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ronaldo with <a href="/wiki/Cristina_Cifuentes" title="Cristina Cifuentes">Cristina Cifuentes</a>, <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Community_of_Madrid" title="President of the Community of Madrid">President of the Community of Madrid</a>, during Champions League title celebrations in Madrid in 2016</div></div></div>
<p>In the <a href="/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_UEFA_Champions_League" title="2016–17 UEFA Champions League">2016–17 UEFA Champions League</a> quarter-final against Bayern Munich in April, Ronaldo scored both goals in a 2–1 away win which saw him make history in becoming the first player to reach 100 goals in UEFA club competition.<sup id="cite_ref-centurion100_218-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-centurion100-218">&#91;214&#93;</a></sup> In the second leg of the quarter-finals, Ronaldo scored a 'perfect' hat-trick and reached his 100th UEFA Champions League goal, becoming the first player to do so as Real Madrid again defeated Bayern 4–2 after <a href="/wiki/Overtime_(sports)" title="Overtime (sports)">extra-time</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-championsleague100_219-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-championsleague100-219">&#91;215&#93;</a></sup> On 2 May, Ronaldo scored another hat-trick as Real Madrid defeated Atlético Madrid 3–0 in the Champions League semi-final first leg. On 17 May, Ronaldo overtook <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Greaves" title="Jimmy Greaves">Jimmy Greaves</a> as the all-time top scorer in the top five European leagues, scoring twice against Celta de Vigo.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">&#91;216&#93;</a></sup> He finished the season with 42 goals in all competitions as he helped Madrid to win their <a href="/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_La_Liga" title="2016–17 La Liga">first La Liga</a> title since 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">&#91;217&#93;</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/2017_UEFA_Champions_League_Final" title="2017 UEFA Champions League Final">2017 Champions League final</a>, Ronaldo scored two goals in the victory against Juventus and became the top goalscorer for the fifth-straight season, and sixth overall, with 12 goals, while also becoming the first player to score in three finals in the Champions League era as well as reaching his 600th senior career goal.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">&#91;218&#93;</a></sup> Madrid also became the first team to win back-to-back finals in the Champions League era.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">&#91;219&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:171px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ronaldo_in_2018.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Ronaldo_in_2018.jpg/169px-Ronaldo_in_2018.jpg" decoding="async" width="169" height="200" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Ronaldo_in_2018.jpg/253px-Ronaldo_in_2018.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Ronaldo_in_2018.jpg/338px-Ronaldo_in_2018.jpg 2x" data-file-width="844" data-file-height="1000" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Ronaldo_in_2018.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ronaldo in the <a href="/wiki/2018_UEFA_Champions_League_Final" title="2018 UEFA Champions League Final">2018 UEFA Champions League Final</a>, his final game for Real Madrid</div></div></div>
<p>At the start of the 2017–18 season, Ronaldo scored Madrid's second goal in a 3–1 <a href="/wiki/2017_Supercopa_de_Espa%C3%B1a" title="2017 Supercopa de España">Supercopa de España</a> first-leg victory over Barcelona at Camp Nou.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">&#91;220&#93;</a></sup> On 23 October, his performances in the first half of 2017 saw him claim his fifth FIFA Player of the Year award by receiving <a href="/wiki/The_Best_FIFA_Football_Awards_2017#The_Best_FIFA_Men&#39;s_Player" title="The Best FIFA Football Awards 2017">The Best FIFA Men's Player</a> award for the second consecutive year.<sup id="cite_ref-The_Best_FIFA_Men&#39;s_Player_225-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Best_FIFA_Men&#39;s_Player-225">&#91;221&#93;</a></sup> On 6 December, he became the first player to score in all six Champions League group stage matches with a curling strike at home to Borussia Dortmund.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">&#91;222&#93;</a></sup> A day later, Ronaldo won the <a href="/wiki/2017_Ballon_d%27Or" title="2017 Ballon d&#39;Or">Ballon d'Or</a> for a fifth time, receiving the award on the <a href="/wiki/Eiffel_Tower" title="Eiffel Tower">Eiffel Tower</a> in Paris.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">&#91;223&#93;</a></sup> On 16 December he scored a free kick winner as Madrid won their second <a href="/wiki/FIFA_Club_World_Cup" title="FIFA Club World Cup">FIFA Club World Cup</a> title in a row by beating Gremio in the <a href="/wiki/2017_FIFA_Club_World_Cup_Final" title="2017 FIFA Club World Cup Final">final</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">&#91;224&#93;</a></sup> On 3 March 2018, he scored two goals in a 3–1 home win over Getafe, his first being his 300th La Liga goal in his 286th La Liga appearance, making him the fastest player to reach this landmark and only the second player to do so after Messi.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">&#91;225&#93;</a></sup> On 18 March, he reached his 50th career hat-trick, scoring four goals in a 6–3 win against <a href="/wiki/Girona_FC" title="Girona FC">Girona</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">&#91;226&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 3 April, Ronaldo scored the first two goals in a 3–0 away win against Juventus in the <a href="/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_UEFA_Champions_League_knockout_phase#Juventus_v_Real_Madrid" title="2017–18 UEFA Champions League knockout phase">quarter-finals</a> of the <a href="/wiki/2017%E2%80%9318_UEFA_Champions_League" title="2017–18 UEFA Champions League">2017–18 UEFA Champions League</a>, with his second goal being an acrobatic <a href="/wiki/Bicycle_kick" title="Bicycle kick">bicycle kick</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">&#91;227&#93;</a></sup> Described as a "<a href="/wiki/PlayStation" title="PlayStation">PlayStation</a> goal" by Juventus defender <a href="/wiki/Andrea_Barzagli" title="Andrea Barzagli">Andrea Barzagli</a>, with Ronaldo's foot approximately 7&#160;ft 7&#160;in (2.31&#160;m) off the ground, it garnered him a standing ovation from the opposing fans in the stadium, as well as a plethora of plaudits from peers, pundits and coaches.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">&#91;228&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">&#91;229&#93;</a></sup> On 11 April, he scored the goal Real Madrid needed to advance to the semi-final, in the second leg of the Champions League quarter-final at home to Juventus, from a 98th-minute injury time penalty in a 3–1 defeat, with an overall 4–3 aggregate win.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">&#91;230&#93;</a></sup> It was also his tenth goal against Juventus, a Champions League record against a single club.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_235-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-235">&#91;231&#93;</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/2018_UEFA_Champions_League_Final" title="2018 UEFA Champions League Final">the final of the tournament</a>, on 26 May, Real Madrid defeated Liverpool 3–1, winning Ronaldo his fifth Champions League title as he became the first player to win the trophy five times.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">&#91;232&#93;</a></sup> He finished as the top scorer of the tournament for the sixth consecutive season, ending the campaign with 15 goals.<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">&#91;233&#93;</a></sup> After the final, Ronaldo referred to his time with the Champions League winners in the past tense, sparking speculation that he could leave Real Madrid.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">&#91;234&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Juventus">Juventus</span></h3>
<h4><span id="2018.E2.80.932019:_Debut_season_and_first_Serie_A_title"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2018–2019:_Debut_season_and_first_Serie_A_title">2018–2019: Debut season and first Serie A title</span></h4>
<p>Despite months of negotiation to sign a new Real Madrid contract,<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">&#91;235&#93;</a></sup> on 10 July 2018, Ronaldo signed a four-year contract with Italian club <a href="/wiki/Juventus_F.C." title="Juventus F.C.">Juventus</a> after completing a €100 million transfer, which included an additional €12 million in other fees,<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">&#91;236&#93;</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Transfer_(football)" class="mw-redirect" title="Transfer (football)">solidarity contributions</a> to Ronaldo's youth clubs. The transfer was the highest ever for a player over 30 years old,<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">&#91;237&#93;</a></sup> and the highest paid by an Italian club.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">&#91;238&#93;</a></sup> Upon signing, Ronaldo cited his need for a new challenge as his rationale for departing Madrid,<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">&#91;239&#93;</a></sup> but later attributed the transfer to the lack of support he felt was shown by club president <a href="/wiki/Florentino_P%C3%A9rez" title="Florentino Pérez">Florentino Pérez</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">&#91;240&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 16 September, Ronaldo scored his first goals for Juventus in his fourth appearance for the club in a 2–1 home win over <a href="/wiki/U.S._Sassuolo_Calcio" title="U.S. Sassuolo Calcio">Sassuolo</a> in <a href="/wiki/Serie_A" title="Serie A">Serie A</a>. His second was the 400th league goal of his career.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">&#91;241&#93;</a></sup> On 19 September, in his first <a href="/wiki/2018%E2%80%9319_UEFA_Champions_League" title="2018–19 UEFA Champions League">Champions League</a> match for Juventus, he was sent off in the 29th minute for "violent conduct", his first red card in 154 Champions League appearances.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">&#91;242&#93;</a></sup> Ronaldo became the first player in history to win 100 Champions League matches, setting up <a href="/wiki/Mario_Mand%C5%BEuki%C4%87" title="Mario Mandžuki">Mario Mandžuki</a>'s winner in a 1–0 home victory over Valencia, which sealed Juventus's passage to the knock-out stages of the competition.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">&#91;243&#93;</a></sup> In December, he scored his tenth Serie A goal of the season, from the penalty spot, netting the final goal in a 3–0 away win over <a href="/wiki/ACF_Fiorentina%E2%80%93Juventus_F.C._rivalry" title="ACF Fiorentina–Juventus F.C. rivalry">rivals</a> <a href="/wiki/ACF_Fiorentina" title="ACF Fiorentina">Fiorentina</a>; with this goal, Ronaldo became the first Juventus player since <a href="/wiki/John_Charles" title="John Charles">John Charles</a> in 1957 to score 10 goals in his first 14 league games for the club.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">&#91;244&#93;</a></sup> After placing second in both the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Men%27s_Player_of_the_Year_Award#2017–18" title="UEFA Men&#39;s Player of the Year Award">UEFA Men's Player of the Year</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Best_FIFA_Football_Awards_2018#The_Best_FIFA_Men&#39;s_Player" title="The Best FIFA Football Awards 2018">The Best FIFA Men's Player</a> for the first time in three years, behind <a href="/wiki/Luka_Modri%C4%87" title="Luka Modri">Luka Modri</a>, Ronaldo performances in 2018 also saw him voted runner-up for the <a href="/wiki/2018_Ballon_d%27Or" title="2018 Ballon d&#39;Or">2018 Ballon d'Or</a>, finishing once again behind his former Real Madrid teammate.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">&#91;245&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Ronaldo won his first trophy with the club in January 2019, the <a href="/wiki/2018_Supercoppa_Italiana" title="2018 Supercoppa Italiana">2018 Supercoppa Italiana</a>, after he scored the game-winning and only goal from a header against <a href="/wiki/A.C._Milan" title="A.C. Milan">A.C. Milan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">&#91;246&#93;</a></sup> On 10 February, Ronaldo scored in a 3–0 away win over Sassuolo; the ninth consecutive away game in which he had scored for Juventus in the league, which enabled him to equal <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Signori" title="Giuseppe Signori">Giuseppe Signori</a>'s single season Serie A record of <a href="/wiki/Football_records_in_Italy#Most_consecutive_Serie_A_away_appearances_with_at_least_one_goal_scored_in_a_single_season" class="mw-redirect" title="Football records in Italy">most consecutive away games with at least one goal</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">&#91;247&#93;</a></sup> On 12 March, Ronaldo scored a hat-trick in a 3–0 home win against Atlético Madrid in the second leg of the <a href="/wiki/2018%E2%80%9319_UEFA_Champions_League" title="2018–19 UEFA Champions League">Champions League</a> round of 16, helping Juventus overcome a two-goal deficit to reach the quarter-finals.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">&#91;248&#93;</a></sup> The following month, Ronaldo scored his 125th goal in the competition, opening the scoring in a 1–1 away draw in the first leg of Juventus' quarter-final against <a href="/wiki/AFC_Ajax" title="AFC Ajax">Ajax</a>, on 10 April.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">&#91;249&#93;</a></sup> In the second leg in Turin on 16 April, he scored the opening goal of the match in the first half, but Juventus eventually lost the match 2–1, and were eliminated from the competition.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">&#91;250&#93;</a></sup> On 20 April, Ronaldo played in the <i><a href="/wiki/List_of_Italian_football_champions" title="List of Italian football champions">Scudetto</a></i> clinching game against <a href="/wiki/ACF_Fiorentina%E2%80%93Juventus_F.C._rivalry" title="ACF Fiorentina–Juventus F.C. rivalry">rivals</a> <a href="/wiki/ACF_Fiorentina" title="ACF Fiorentina">Fiorentina</a> as Juventus won their eighth successive Serie A title after a 2–1 home win, thereby becoming the first player to win league titles in <a href="/wiki/Premier_League" title="Premier League">England</a>, <a href="/wiki/La_Liga" title="La Liga">Spain</a> and <a href="/wiki/Serie_A" title="Serie A">Italy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">&#91;251&#93;</a></sup> On 27 April, he scored his 600th club goal, the equaliser in a 1–1 away draw against <a href="/wiki/Derby_d%27Italia" title="Derby d&#39;Italia">rivals</a> <a href="/wiki/Inter_Milan" title="Inter Milan">Inter</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">&#91;252&#93;</a></sup> Finishing his first Serie A campaign with 21 goals and 8 assists, Ronaldo won the inaugural <a href="/wiki/Serie_A_Awards" title="Serie A Awards">Serie A Award</a> for Most Valuable Player.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-257">&#91;253&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="2019.E2.80.932020:_Second_consecutive_Serie_A_title"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2019–2020:_Second_consecutive_Serie_A_title">2019–2020: Second consecutive Serie A title</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:CR7_2_11_2019.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/CR7_2_11_2019.jpg/170px-CR7_2_11_2019.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="476" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/CR7_2_11_2019.jpg/255px-CR7_2_11_2019.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d9/CR7_2_11_2019.jpg/340px-CR7_2_11_2019.jpg 2x" data-file-width="888" data-file-height="2484" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:CR7_2_11_2019.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ronaldo appearing for Juventus against <a href="/wiki/Torino_Football_Club" class="mw-redirect" title="Torino Football Club">Torino</a> during the 2019–20 season</div></div></div>
<p>Ronaldo scored his first goal of the <a href="/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_Juventus_F.C._season" title="2019–20 Juventus F.C. season">2019–20 season</a> for Juventus in a 4–3 home win over <a href="/wiki/S.S.C._Napoli" title="S.S.C. Napoli">Napoli</a> in Serie A on 31 August 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">&#91;254&#93;</a></sup> On 23 September, he came in 3rd place for the <a href="/wiki/The_Best_FIFA_Football_Awards_2019#The_Best_FIFA_Men&#39;s_Player" title="The Best FIFA Football Awards 2019">2019 Best FIFA Men's Player Award</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Results_259-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Results-259">&#91;255&#93;</a></sup> On 1 October, he reached several milestones in Juventus's 3–0 group stage win over <a href="/wiki/Bayer_04_Leverkusen" title="Bayer 04 Leverkusen">Bayer Leverkusen</a> in the <a href="/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_UEFA_Champions_League" title="2019–20 UEFA Champions League">Champions League</a>: his goal during the match saw him score for the 14th consecutive Champions League season, equalling Raúl and Messi's record; he also broke <a href="/wiki/Iker_Casillas" title="Iker Casillas">Iker Casillas</a>' record for most Champions League wins of all time, and equalled Raúl's record of scoring against 33 different Champions League opponents.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">&#91;256&#93;</a></sup> On 6 November, in a 2–1 away win against <a href="/wiki/FC_Lokomotiv_Moscow" title="FC Lokomotiv Moscow">Lokomotiv Moscow</a> in the Champions League group stage, he equalled <a href="/wiki/Paolo_Maldini" title="Paolo Maldini">Paolo Maldini</a> as the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_club_competition_records_and_statistics#Top_appearances_in_UEFA_club_competitions" title="UEFA club competition records and statistics">second-most capped player in UEFA club competitions</a> with 174 appearances.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">&#91;257&#93;</a></sup> On 18 December, Ronaldo performed an athletic feet, in leaping to a height of 8.39&#160;ft (2.56m) – higher than the crossbar (8&#160;ft) – before heading the winning goal in a 2–1 away win for Juventus against <a href="/wiki/U.C._Sampdoria" title="U.C. Sampdoria">Sampdoria</a> in Serie A.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">&#91;258&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Ronaldo scored his first Serie A hat-trick on 6 January 2020, in a 4–0 home win against <a href="/wiki/Cagliari_Calcio" title="Cagliari Calcio">Cagliari</a>. His 56th career hat-trick, he became only the second player after <a href="/wiki/Alexis_S%C3%A1nchez" title="Alexis Sánchez">Alexis Sánchez</a> to score hat-tricks in the Premier League, La Liga and Serie A.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">&#91;259&#93;</a></sup> On 2 February, he scored twice from the penalty spot in a 3–0 home win over Fiorentina, equalling <a href="/wiki/David_Trezeguet" title="David Trezeguet">David Trezeguet</a>'s club record of nine consecutive appearances in Serie A with at least one goal.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">&#91;260&#93;</a></sup> He broke the club record six days later, when he scored in his tenth consecutive league game, a 2–1 away defeat to <a href="/wiki/Hellas_Verona_F.C." title="Hellas Verona F.C.">Hellas Verona</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">&#91;261&#93;</a></sup> On 22 February, Ronaldo scored for a <a href="/wiki/Football_records_and_statistics_in_Italy#Most_consecutive_Serie_A_appearances_with_at_least_one_goal_scored_in_a_single_season" title="Football records and statistics in Italy">record-equalling</a> 11th consecutive Serie A game (a record shared with <a href="/wiki/Gabriel_Batistuta" title="Gabriel Batistuta">Gabriel Batistuta</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fabio_Quagliarella" title="Fabio Quagliarella">Fabio Quagliarella</a>), in what was his 1,000th senior professional game, in a 2–1 away win for Juventus against <a href="/wiki/S.P.A.L." title="S.P.A.L.">SPAL</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">&#91;262&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 22 June, he scored a penalty in a 2–0 away win over <a href="/wiki/Bologna_F.C._1909" title="Bologna F.C. 1909">Bologna</a>, overtaking <a href="/wiki/Rui_Costa" title="Rui Costa">Rui Costa</a> to become the highest scoring Portuguese player in Serie A history.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">&#91;263&#93;</a></sup> On 4 July, he assisted <a href="/wiki/Juan_Cuadrado" title="Juan Cuadrado">Juan Cuadrado</a>'s goal and later scored his 25th league goal of the season from a free kick in a 4–1 home win over rivals Torino, becoming the first Juventus player to achieve this milestone since <a href="/wiki/Omar_S%C3%ADvori" title="Omar Sívori">Omar Sívori</a> in <a href="/wiki/1960%E2%80%9361_Serie_A" title="1960–61 Serie A">1961</a>; the goal was also his first from a free kick with the club, after 43 attempts.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">&#91;264&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 20 July, Ronaldo scored twice in a 2–1 home win over <a href="/wiki/S.S._Lazio" title="S.S. Lazio">Lazio</a>; his first goal was his 50th in Serie A. He became the second fastest player to reach this landmark, after <a href="/wiki/Gunnar_Nordahl" title="Gunnar Nordahl">Gunnar Nordahl</a>, and the first player in history to reach 50 goals in the Premier League, La Liga, and Serie A. With his brace, he also reached 30 league goals for the season, becoming just the third player in Juventus's history to reach that milestone in a single season,<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">&#91;265&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">&#91;266&#93;</a></sup> after <a href="/wiki/Felice_Borel" title="Felice Borel">Felice Borel</a> in <a href="/wiki/1933%E2%80%9334_Serie_A" title="1933–34 Serie A">1933–34</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Hansen_(footballer,_born_1924)" title="John Hansen (footballer, born 1924)">John Hansen</a> in <a href="/wiki/1951%E2%80%9352_Serie_A" title="1951–52 Serie A">1951–52</a>. Moreover, he became the oldest player, at the age of 35 years and 166 days, to score more than 30 goals in one of the five top European leagues since <a href="/wiki/Ronnie_Rooke" title="Ronnie Rooke">Ronnie Rooke</a> with Arsenal in 1948.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">&#91;267&#93;</a></sup> On 26 July, he scored the opening goal in a 2–0 home win over Sampdoria, which saw Juventus crowned Serie A champions for a ninth consecutive time.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">&#91;268&#93;</a></sup> He finished his second Serie A campaign with a total of 31 goals and 6 assists, which made him the second–highest goalscorer in the league behind only European Golden Shoe winner <a href="/wiki/Ciro_Immobile" title="Ciro Immobile">Ciro Immobile</a>, with 36 goals, who also equalled <a href="/wiki/Gonzalo_Higua%C3%ADn" title="Gonzalo Higuaín">Gonzalo Higuaín</a>'s record for most goals in a single Serie A season.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">&#91;269&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">&#91;270&#93;</a></sup> On 7 August, Ronaldo scored a brace in a 2–1 home win against Lyon in the second leg of the Champions League round of 16, which saw him finish the season with 37 goals in all competitions; the tally allowed him to break Felice Borel's club record of 36 goals in a single season, which he had set in 1933–34.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">&#91;271&#93;</a></sup> However, despite the victory, Juventus tied with Lyon 2–2 on aggregate, and were eliminated from the competition on the away goals rule.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">&#91;272&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="2020.E2.80.93present:_Third_season_in_Italy"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2020–present:_Third_season_in_Italy">2020–present: Third season in Italy</span></h4>
<p>On 20 September 2020, Ronaldo scored in Juventus's opening match of the season, a 3–0 home win over Sampdoria in Serie A.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">&#91;273&#93;</a></sup> On 1 November, after Ronaldo took nearly three weeks to recover from <a href="/wiki/COVID-19" title="COVID-19">COVID-19</a>, he returned to action against <a href="/wiki/Spezia_Calcio" title="Spezia Calcio">Spezia</a> where he came off the bench in the second half and scored within the first three minutes. He later scored a second goal from the penalty spot in an eventual 4–1 away win.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">&#91;274&#93;</a></sup> On 2 December, he scored a goal against <a href="/wiki/FC_Dynamo_Kyiv" title="FC Dynamo Kyiv">Dynamo Kyiv</a> in a <a href="/wiki/2020%E2%80%9321_UEFA_Champions_League" title="2020–21 UEFA Champions League">Champions League</a> group stage match to reach his 750th senior career goal.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">&#91;275&#93;</a></sup> Ronaldo played his 100th match in all competitions for Juventus on 13 December, scoring two penalties in a 3–1 away win to Genoa in the league, and bringing his goal tally to 79.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">&#91;276&#93;</a></sup> On 2 March 2021, he scored a goal in a 3–0 win over <a href="/wiki/Spezia_Calcio" title="Spezia Calcio">Spezia</a> in his 600th league match, to become the first player to score at least 20 goals in each of the past 12 consecutive seasons in the top five leagues of Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">&#91;277&#93;</a></sup> On 9 March, Juventus were knocked out of the Champions League at the round of 16 by Porto on the away goals rule (4–4 on aggregate).<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">&#91;278&#93;</a></sup> On 14 March, he scored his 57th career hat-trick in a 3–1 away win over Cagliari.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">&#91;279&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="International_career">International career</span></h2>
<h3><span id="2001.E2.80.932007:_Youth_level_and_early_international_career"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2001–2007:_Youth_level_and_early_international_career">2001–2007: Youth level and early international career</span></h3>
<p>Ronaldo began his international career with Portugal <a href="/wiki/Portugal_national_under-15_football_team" title="Portugal national under-15 football team">under-15</a> in 2001. During his international youth career, Ronaldo would represent the under-15, <a href="/wiki/Portugal_national_under-17_football_team" title="Portugal national under-17 football team">under-17</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portugal_national_under-20_football_team" title="Portugal national under-20 football team">under-20</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portugal_national_under-21_football_team" title="Portugal national under-21 football team">under-21</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Portugal_Olympic_football_team" title="Portugal Olympic football team">under-23</a> national sides, amassing 34 youth caps and scoring 18 goals overall.<sup id="cite_ref-FPF_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FPF-8">&#91;8&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>At age 18, Ronaldo made his first senior appearance for <a href="/wiki/Portugal_national_football_team" title="Portugal national football team">Portugal</a> in a 1–0 victory over <a href="/wiki/Kazakhstan_national_football_team" title="Kazakhstan national football team">Kazakhstan</a> on 20 August 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">&#91;280&#93;</a></sup> He was subsequently called up for <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2004" title="UEFA Euro 2004">UEFA Euro 2004</a>, held in his home country, and scored his first international goal in a 2–1 group stage loss to eventual champions <a href="/wiki/Greece_national_football_team" title="Greece national football team">Greece</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">&#91;281&#93;</a></sup> After converting his penalty in a shoot-out against <a href="/wiki/England_national_football_team" title="England national football team">England</a> in the quarter-finals,<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">&#91;282&#93;</a></sup> he helped Portugal reach the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2004_Final" title="UEFA Euro 2004 Final">final</a> by scoring the opening goal in a 2–1 win over the <a href="/wiki/Netherlands_national_football_team" title="Netherlands national football team">Netherlands</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">&#91;283&#93;</a></sup> He was featured in the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_European_Championship_awards#Team_of_the_Tournament" title="UEFA European Championship awards">team of the tournament</a>, having provided two assists in addition to his two goals.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">&#91;284&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Ronaldo was Portugal's second-highest scorer in their <a href="/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_%E2%80%93_UEFA_Group_3" title="2006 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Group 3">qualification group</a> for the <a href="/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2006 FIFA World Cup">2006 FIFA World Cup</a> with seven goals.<sup id="cite_ref-Ronaldo_profile_289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ronaldo_profile-289">&#91;285&#93;</a></sup> During the tournament, he scored his first World Cup goal against <a href="/wiki/Iran_national_football_team" title="Iran national football team">Iran</a> with a penalty kick in Portugal's second match of the group stage.<sup id="cite_ref-Por._Vs_Iran_290-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Por._Vs_Iran-290">&#91;286&#93;</a></sup> In Portugal's round of 16 match against the Netherlands, an <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Nuremberg_(2006_FIFA_World_Cup)" title="Battle of Nuremberg (2006 FIFA World Cup)">infamously dirty game</a>, Ronaldo was forced off injured in the first half, following a tackle from Dutch defender <a href="/wiki/Khalid_Boulahrouz" title="Khalid Boulahrouz">Khalid Boulahrouz</a>. Following Portugal's 1–0 victory in the match, Ronaldo accused Boulahrouz of intentionally trying to injure him, although he was able to recover in time to participate in the next round.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">&#91;287&#93;</a></sup> In Portugal's quarter-final against England, Ronaldo's Manchester United teammate Wayne Rooney was sent off for stamping on Portugal defender <a href="/wiki/Ricardo_Carvalho" title="Ricardo Carvalho">Ricardo Carvalho</a>. Although the referee later clarified that the red card was only due to Rooney's infraction,<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">&#91;288&#93;</a></sup> the English media speculated that Ronaldo had influenced his decision by aggressively complaining, after which he was seen in replays winking at Portugal's bench following Rooney's dismissal.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">&#91;289&#93;</a></sup> Ronaldo went on to score the vital winning penalty during the shoot-out which sent Portugal into the semi-finals.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">&#91;290&#93;</a></sup> Ronaldo was subsequently booed during their 1–0 semi-final defeat to <a href="/wiki/France_national_football_team" title="France national football team">France</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">&#91;291&#93;</a></sup> FIFA's Technical Study Group overlooked him for the tournament's Best Young Player award and handed it to <a href="/wiki/Germany_national_football_team" title="Germany national football team">Germany</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Lukas_Podolski" title="Lukas Podolski">Lukas Podolski</a>, citing his behaviour as a factor in the decision.<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">&#91;292&#93;</a></sup> Following the 2006 World Cup, Ronaldo would go on to represent Portugal in four qualifying games for <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2008" title="UEFA Euro 2008">Euro 2008</a>, scoring two goals in the process.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">&#91;293&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">&#91;294&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="2007.E2.80.932012:_Assuming_the_captaincy"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2007–2012:_Assuming_the_captaincy">2007–2012: Assuming the captaincy</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo_20120609.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Cristiano_Ronaldo_20120609.jpg/170px-Cristiano_Ronaldo_20120609.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="256" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Cristiano_Ronaldo_20120609.jpg/255px-Cristiano_Ronaldo_20120609.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Cristiano_Ronaldo_20120609.jpg/340px-Cristiano_Ronaldo_20120609.jpg 2x" data-file-width="435" data-file-height="656" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo_20120609.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ronaldo, pictured playing against <a href="/wiki/Germany_national_football_team" title="Germany national football team">Germany</a> at <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2012" title="UEFA Euro 2012">Euro 2012</a>, was made captain for Portugal in 2008.</div></div></div>
<p>One day after his 22nd birthday, Ronaldo <a href="/wiki/List_of_Portugal_national_football_team_captains" title="List of Portugal national football team captains">captained</a> Portugal for the first time in a friendly game against <a href="/wiki/Brazil_national_football_team" title="Brazil national football team">Brazil</a> on 6 February 2007,<sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">&#91;295&#93;</a></sup> as requested by <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Football_Federation" title="Portuguese Football Federation">Portuguese Football Federation</a> president Carlos Silva, who had died two days earlier.<sup id="cite_ref-Rediff_captain_300-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rediff_captain-300">&#91;296&#93;</a></sup> Ahead of Euro 2008, he was given the number 7 shirt for the first time.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">&#91;297&#93;</a></sup> While he scored eight goals in the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2008_qualification" class="mw-redirect" title="UEFA Euro 2008 qualification">qualification</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">&#91;298&#93;</a></sup> the second-highest tally, he scored just one goal in the tournament, netting the second goal of their 3–1 win in the group stage match against the <a href="/wiki/Czech_Republic_national_football_team" title="Czech Republic national football team">Czech Republic</a>; in the same game, he also set-up Portugal's third goal in injury time, which was scored by Quaresma, and was named man of the match for his performance.<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">&#91;299&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">&#91;300&#93;</a></sup> Portugal were eliminated in the quarter-finals with a 3–2 loss against eventual finalists Germany.<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">&#91;301&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>After Portugal's unsuccessful performance in the European Championship, <a href="/wiki/Luiz_Felipe_Scolari" title="Luiz Felipe Scolari">Luiz Felipe Scolari</a> was replaced as coach by Carlos Queiroz, formerly the assistant manager at United.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">&#91;302&#93;</a></sup> Queiroz made Ronaldo the squad's permanent captain in July 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">&#91;303&#93;</a></sup> Ronaldo failed to score a single goal in the <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_(UEFA)" title="2010 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)">qualification</a> for the <a href="/wiki/2010_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2010 FIFA World Cup">2010 World Cup</a>, as Portugal narrowly avoided a premature elimination from the tournament with a play-off victory over <a href="/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina_national_football_team" title="Bosnia and Herzegovina national football team">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">&#91;304&#93;</a></sup> In the group stage of the World Cup, he was named man of the match in all three matches against <a href="/wiki/Ivory_Coast_national_football_team" title="Ivory Coast national football team">Ivory Coast</a>, <a href="/wiki/North_Korea_national_football_team" title="North Korea national football team">North Korea</a>, and Brazil.<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">&#91;305&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">&#91;306&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">&#91;307&#93;</a></sup> His only goal of the tournament came in their 7–0 rout of North Korea, which marked his first international goal in 16 months.<sup id="cite_ref-wsj_312-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wsj-312">&#91;308&#93;</a></sup> Portugal's World Cup ended with a 1–0 loss against eventual champions <a href="/wiki/Spain_national_football_team" title="Spain national football team">Spain</a> in the round of 16.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">&#91;309&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Ronaldo scored seven goals in the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2012_qualifying" title="UEFA Euro 2012 qualifying">qualification</a> for <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2012" title="UEFA Euro 2012">Euro 2012</a>, including two strikes against Bosnia and Herzegovina in the play-offs, to send Portugal into the tournament, where they were drawn in a "<a href="/wiki/Group_of_death" title="Group of death">group of death</a>".<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">&#91;310&#93;</a></sup> In the last group stage game against the Netherlands, Ronaldo scored twice to secure a 2–1 victory.<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">&#91;311&#93;</a></sup> He scored a header in the quarter-final against the Czech Republic to give his team a 1–0 win.<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">&#91;312&#93;</a></sup> In both games against the Netherlands and the Czech Republic he was named man of the match.<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">&#91;313&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">&#91;314&#93;</a></sup> After the semi-finals against Spain ended scoreless, with Ronaldo having sent three shots over the bar,<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">&#91;315&#93;</a></sup> Portugal were eliminated in the penalty shoot-out. Ronaldo did not take a penalty as he had been slated to take the unused fifth slot,<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">&#91;316&#93;</a></sup> a decision that was questioned by the media<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">&#91;317&#93;</a></sup> and later criticized by Frank Wagner and Beau Bourne of <a href="/wiki/Bleacher_Report" title="Bleacher Report">Bleacher Report</a>, Graham MacAree of <i><a href="/wiki/SB_Nation" title="SB Nation">SB Nation</a></i> and by <a href="/wiki/Yahoo_Sports" title="Yahoo Sports">Yahoo Sports</a>' Martin Rogers.<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">&#91;318&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">&#91;319&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">&#91;320&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">&#91;321&#93;</a></sup> Ronaldo's own teammate, <a href="/wiki/Nani_(footballer)" title="Nani (footballer)">Nani</a>, said that Ronaldo "demanded" to take the last penalty.<sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">&#91;322&#93;</a></sup> As the joint top scorer with three goals, alongside five other players, he was again included in the team of the tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">&#91;323&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="2012.E2.80.932016:_All-time_Portugal_top_scorer_and_European_champion"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2012–2016:_All-time_Portugal_top_scorer_and_European_champion">2012–2016: All-time Portugal top scorer and European champion</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo_(L),_Luka_Modric_(R)_-_Croatia_vs._Portugal,_10th_June_2013.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Cristiano_Ronaldo_%28L%29%2C_Luka_Modric_%28R%29_-_Croatia_vs._Portugal%2C_10th_June_2013.jpg/260px-Cristiano_Ronaldo_%28L%29%2C_Luka_Modric_%28R%29_-_Croatia_vs._Portugal%2C_10th_June_2013.jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="173" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Cristiano_Ronaldo_%28L%29%2C_Luka_Modric_%28R%29_-_Croatia_vs._Portugal%2C_10th_June_2013.jpg/390px-Cristiano_Ronaldo_%28L%29%2C_Luka_Modric_%28R%29_-_Croatia_vs._Portugal%2C_10th_June_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Cristiano_Ronaldo_%28L%29%2C_Luka_Modric_%28R%29_-_Croatia_vs._Portugal%2C_10th_June_2013.jpg/520px-Cristiano_Ronaldo_%28L%29%2C_Luka_Modric_%28R%29_-_Croatia_vs._Portugal%2C_10th_June_2013.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3401" data-file-height="2267" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Cristiano_Ronaldo_(L),_Luka_Modric_(R)_-_Croatia_vs._Portugal,_10th_June_2013.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ronaldo evading <a href="/wiki/Luka_Modri%C4%87" title="Luka Modri">Luka Modri</a> during a friendly match against <a href="/wiki/Croatia_national_football_team" title="Croatia national football team">Croatia</a> in 2013</div></div></div>
<p>During the <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_(UEFA)" title="2014 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)">qualification</a> for the <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2014 FIFA World Cup">2014 World Cup</a>, Ronaldo scored a total of eight goals. A qualifying match on 17 October 2012, a 1–1 draw against <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_national_football_team" title="Northern Ireland national football team">Northern Ireland</a>, earned him his <a href="/wiki/List_of_men%27s_footballers_with_100_or_more_international_caps" title="List of men&#39;s footballers with 100 or more international caps">100th cap</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328">&#91;324&#93;</a></sup> His first international hat-trick also came against Northern Ireland, when he found the net three times in a 15-minute spell of a 4–2 qualifying victory on 6 September 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">&#91;325&#93;</a></sup> After Portugal failed to qualify during the regular campaign, Ronaldo scored all four of the team's goals in the play-offs against <a href="/wiki/Sweden_national_football_team" title="Sweden national football team">Sweden</a> – billed as a battle between Ronaldo and <a href="/wiki/Zlatan_Ibrahimovi%C4%87" title="Zlatan Ibrahimovi">Zlatan Ibrahimovi</a> – which ensured their place at the tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">&#91;326&#93;</a></sup> His hat-trick in the second leg took his international tally to 47 goals, equaling <a href="/wiki/Pauleta" title="Pauleta">Pauleta</a>'s record.<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">&#91;327&#93;</a></sup> Ronaldo subsequently scored twice in a 5–1 friendly win over <a href="/wiki/Cameroon_national_football_team" title="Cameroon national football team">Cameroon</a> on 5 March 2014 to become his country's <a href="/wiki/Portugal_national_football_team#Top_goalscorers" title="Portugal national football team">all-time top scorer</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">&#91;328&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>Ronaldo took part in the tournament despite suffering from patellar tendinitis and a related thigh injury,<sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333">&#91;329&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">&#91;330&#93;</a></sup> potentially risking his career.<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">&#91;331&#93;</a></sup> Ronaldo later commented: "If we had two or three Cristiano Ronaldos in the team I would feel more comfortable. But we don't."<sup id="cite_ref-TG_336-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TG-336">&#91;332&#93;</a></sup> Despite ongoing doubts over his fitness, being forced to abort practice twice,<sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">&#91;333&#93;</a></sup> Ronaldo played the full 90 minutes of the opening match against Germany, though he was unable to prevent a 4–0 defeat.<sup id="cite_ref-injury_338-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-injury-338">&#91;334&#93;</a></sup> After assisting an injury-time 2–2 equaliser against the <a href="/wiki/United_States_men%27s_national_soccer_team" title="United States men&#39;s national soccer team">United States</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">&#91;335&#93;</a></sup> he scored a late match-winning goal in a 2–1 victory over <a href="/wiki/Ghana_national_football_team" title="Ghana national football team">Ghana</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC14_340-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC14-340">&#91;336&#93;</a></sup> His <a href="/wiki/List_of_men%27s_footballers_with_50_or_more_international_goals" title="List of men&#39;s footballers with 50 or more international goals">50th international goal</a> made him the first Portuguese to play and score in three World Cups.<sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">&#91;337&#93;</a></sup> Portugal were eliminated from the tournament at the close of the group stage on goal difference.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC14_340-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC14-340">&#91;336&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a href="/wiki/File:1_cristiano_ronaldo_2016.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/1_cristiano_ronaldo_2016.jpg/170px-1_cristiano_ronaldo_2016.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="226" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/1_cristiano_ronaldo_2016.jpg/255px-1_cristiano_ronaldo_2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/1_cristiano_ronaldo_2016.jpg/340px-1_cristiano_ronaldo_2016.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3696" data-file-height="4912" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:1_cristiano_ronaldo_2016.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ronaldo leaps in the air in Portugal's <a href="/wiki/Euro_2016" class="mw-redirect" title="Euro 2016">Euro 2016</a> quarter-final match against <a href="/wiki/Poland_national_football_team" title="Poland national football team">Poland</a></div></div></div>
<p>Ronaldo scored five goals, including a hat-trick against <a href="/wiki/Armenia_national_football_team" title="Armenia national football team">Armenia</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016_qualifying" title="UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying">qualification</a> for <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016" title="UEFA Euro 2016">Euro 2016</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">&#91;338&#93;</a></sup> With the only goal in another victory over Armenia on 14 November 2014, he reached 23 goals in the European Championship, including qualifying matches, to become the competition's <a href="/wiki/List_of_UEFA_European_Championship_records#Goalscoring" class="mw-redirect" title="List of UEFA European Championship records">all-time leading goalscorer</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-twentythree_343-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-twentythree-343">&#91;339&#93;</a></sup> At the start of the tournament, however, Ronaldo failed to convert his chances in Portugal's draws against <a href="/wiki/Iceland_national_football_team" title="Iceland national football team">Iceland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Austria_national_football_team" title="Austria national football team">Austria</a>, despite taking a total of 20 shots on goal. In the latter match, he overtook Luís Figo as his <a href="/wiki/Portugal_national_football_team#Most_appearances" title="Portugal national football team">nation's most capped player</a> with his 128th international appearance, which ended scoreless after he missed a penalty in the second half.<sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344">&#91;340&#93;</a></sup> With two goals and an assist in the last match of the group stage, a 3–3 draw against <a href="/wiki/Hungary_national_football_team" title="Hungary national football team">Hungary</a>, Ronaldo became the first player to score in four European Championships, having made a <a href="/wiki/List_of_UEFA_European_Championship_records#Individual" class="mw-redirect" title="List of UEFA European Championship records">record 17 appearances</a> in the tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">&#91;341&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">&#91;342&#93;</a></sup> Though placed third in their group behind Hungary and Iceland, his team qualified for the knockout round as a result of the competition's newly expanded format.<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">&#91;343&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In Portugal's first knockout match, Ronaldo's only attempt on goal was parried by <a href="/wiki/Croatia_national_football_team" title="Croatia national football team">Croatia</a>'s goalkeeper into the path of <a href="/wiki/Ricardo_Quaresma" title="Ricardo Quaresma">Ricardo Quaresma</a>, whose finish then secured a 1–0 victory late in extra time.<sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">&#91;344&#93;</a></sup> After his team progressed past <a href="/wiki/Poland_national_football_team" title="Poland national football team">Poland</a> on penalties,<sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">&#91;345&#93;</a></sup> Ronaldo became the first player to participate in three European Championship semi-finals;<sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350">&#91;346&#93;</a></sup> he scored the opening goal and assisted a second in a 2–0 win against <a href="/wiki/Wales_national_football_team" title="Wales national football team">Wales</a>, equaling <a href="/wiki/Michel_Platini" title="Michel Platini">Michel Platini</a> as the competition's all-time top scorer with nine goals.<sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351">&#91;347&#93;</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016_Final" title="UEFA Euro 2016 Final">final</a> against hosts France, Ronaldo was forced off after just 25 minutes following a challenge from <a href="/wiki/Dimitri_Payet" title="Dimitri Payet">Dimitri Payet</a>. After multiple treatments and attempts to play on, he was stretchered off the pitch and replaced by Quaresma. During extra time, substitute <a href="/wiki/Eder_(Portuguese_footballer)" title="Eder (Portuguese footballer)">Eder</a> scored in the 109th minute to earn Portugal a 1–0 victory.<sup id="cite_ref-Euro_2016_final_352-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Euro_2016_final-352">&#91;348&#93;</a></sup> As team captain, Ronaldo later lifted the trophy in celebration of his country's first triumph in a major tournament. He was awarded the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2016#Awards" title="UEFA Euro 2016">Silver Boot</a> as the joint second-highest goalscorer, with three goals and three assists, and was named to the team of the tournament for the third time in his career.<sup id="cite_ref-team_of_the_tournament_353-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-team_of_the_tournament-353">&#91;349&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-golden-boot-winner_354-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-golden-boot-winner-354">&#91;350&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="2016.E2.80.932018:_Post-European_Championship_victory.2C_and_World_Cup"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2016–2018:_Post-European_Championship_victory,_and_World_Cup">2016–2018: Post-European Championship victory, and World Cup</span></h3>
<p>Following the Euro 2016 success, Ronaldo played his first professional match on his home island of Madeira on 28 March 2017 at age 32, opening a 2–3 friendly defeat to Sweden at the <a href="/wiki/Est%C3%A1dio_dos_Barreiros" class="mw-redirect" title="Estádio dos Barreiros">Estádio dos Barreiros</a>. With the goal, he tied with <a href="/wiki/Miroslav_Klose" title="Miroslav Klose">Miroslav Klose</a> on 71 goals as the third-highest scoring European in international football.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">&#91;351&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>In Portugal's opening match of the <a href="/wiki/2017_FIFA_Confederations_Cup" title="2017 FIFA Confederations Cup">2017 FIFA Confederations Cup</a> against <a href="/wiki/Mexico_national_football_team" title="Mexico national football team">Mexico</a> on 17 June, Cristiano Ronaldo set-up Quaresma's opening goal in a 2–2 draw.<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">&#91;352&#93;</a></sup> Three days later, he scored in a 1–0 win over hosts <a href="/wiki/Russia_national_football_team" title="Russia national football team">Russia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357">&#91;353&#93;</a></sup> On 24 June, he scored from a penalty in a 4–0 win over <a href="/wiki/New_Zealand_national_football_team" title="New Zealand national football team">New Zealand</a>, which saw Portugal top their group and advance to the semi-finals of the competition. With his 75th international goal, Ronaldo also equalled <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A1ndor_Kocsis" title="Sándor Kocsis">Sándor Kocsis</a> as the second-highest European international goalscorer of all-time, behind only Ferenc Puskás.<sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">&#91;354&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">&#91;355&#93;</a></sup> He was named man of the match in all three of Portugal's group stage matches.<sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">&#91;356&#93;</a></sup> Ronaldo left the competition early: after <a href="/wiki/Chile_national_football_team" title="Chile national football team">Chile</a> defeated Portugal 3–0 on penalties in the <a href="/wiki/2017_FIFA_Confederations_Cup#Semi-finals" title="2017 FIFA Confederations Cup">semi-finals</a>, he was allowed to return home to be with his newborn children.<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">&#91;357&#93;</a></sup> Therefore, he missed Portugal's <a href="/wiki/2017_FIFA_Confederations_Cup#Third_place_play-off" title="2017 FIFA Confederations Cup">third-place play-off</a> match in which Portugal defeated Mexico 2–1 after extra time.<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">&#91;358&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:232px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Portugal_and_Iran_match_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup_2018_9.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Portugal_and_Iran_match_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup_2018_9.jpg/230px-Portugal_and_Iran_match_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup_2018_9.jpg" decoding="async" width="230" height="197" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Portugal_and_Iran_match_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup_2018_9.jpg/345px-Portugal_and_Iran_match_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup_2018_9.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Portugal_and_Iran_match_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup_2018_9.jpg/460px-Portugal_and_Iran_match_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup_2018_9.jpg 2x" data-file-width="995" data-file-height="853" /></a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Portugal_and_Iran_match_at_the_FIFA_World_Cup_2018_9.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ronaldo evades an <a href="/wiki/Iran_national_football_team" title="Iran national football team">Iran</a> defender in the group stage of the <a href="/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2018 FIFA World Cup">2018 FIFA World Cup</a></div></div></div><p>On 31 August 2017, Ronaldo scored a hat-trick in a 5–1 win in a World Cup qualifier over the <a href="/wiki/Faroe_Islands_national_football_team" title="Faroe Islands national football team">Faroe Islands</a>, which saw him overtake Pelé and equal <a href="/wiki/Hussein_Saeed" title="Hussein Saeed">Hussein Saeed</a> as the joint-fifth-highest goalscorer in international football with 78 goals.<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">&#91;359&#93;</a></sup> These goals brought his tally in the 2018 World Cup qualifiers to 14, equalling <a href="/wiki/Predrag_Mijatovi%C4%87" title="Predrag Mijatovi">Predrag Mijatovi</a>'s record for most goals in a single UEFA senior men's qualifying campaign, and also saw him break the record for the most goals scored in a single European qualifying group, overtaking the previous record of 13 goals set by <a href="/wiki/David_Healy_(footballer)" title="David Healy (footballer)">David Healy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Robert_Lewandowski" title="Robert Lewandowski">Robert Lewandowski</a>. Ronaldo's hat-trick took his World Cup qualifying goals total to 29, making him the highest scorer in European World Cup qualifiers, ahead of <a href="/wiki/Andriy_Shevchenko" title="Andriy Shevchenko">Andriy Shevchenko</a>, and the highest goalscorer in World Cup qualifying and finals matches combined, with 32 goals, ahead of Miroslav Klose.<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364">&#91;360&#93;</a></sup> Ronaldo later added to this tally by scoring a goal against Andorra in a 2–0 victory.<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">&#91;361&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 15 June 2018, Ronaldo became the oldest player to score a <a href="/wiki/List_of_FIFA_World_Cup_hat-tricks" title="List of FIFA World Cup hat-tricks">hat-trick</a> in a World Cup match, helping Portugal secure a 3–3 draw against Spain (his third goal a 30-yard curling free kick with two minutes remaining) in their opening match. In doing so, he also became the first Portuguese player to score a goal in four World Cups and one of four players to do so in total.<sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">&#91;362&#93;</a></sup> On 20 June, Ronaldo scored the only goal in a 1–0 victory against <a href="/wiki/Morocco_national_football_team" title="Morocco national football team">Morocco</a>, breaking <a href="/wiki/Ferenc_Pusk%C3%A1s" title="Ferenc Puskás">Ferenc Puskás</a>’ record as the highest European goalscorer of all-time, with 85 international goals.<sup id="cite_ref-CR7vmorocco_367-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CR7vmorocco-367">&#91;363&#93;</a></sup> In the final group match against <a href="/wiki/Iran_national_football_team" title="Iran national football team">Iran</a> on 25 June, Ronaldo missed a penalty in an eventual 1–1 draw which saw Portugal progress to the second round as group runners-up behind Spain.<sup id="cite_ref-368" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-368">&#91;364&#93;</a></sup> On 30 June, Portugal were eliminated following a 2–1 defeat to <a href="/wiki/Uruguay_national_football_team" title="Uruguay national football team">Uruguay</a> in the last 16.<sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">&#91;365&#93;</a></sup> For his performances in the tournament, Ronaldo was later named to the <a href="/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup#Dream_Team" title="2018 FIFA World Cup">2018 FIFA World Cup Dream Team</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-2018_FWC_Dream_Team_370-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2018_FWC_Dream_Team-370">&#91;366&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="2018.E2.80.93present:_Nations_League_title_and_century_of_international_goals"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2018–present:_Nations_League_title_and_century_of_international_goals">2018–present: Nations League title and century of international goals</span></h3>
<p>After the 2018 FIFA World Cup, Ronaldo missed six international matches, including the entire league phase of the <a href="/wiki/2018%E2%80%9319_UEFA_Nations_League" title="2018–19 UEFA Nations League">2018–19 UEFA Nations League</a>. Ronaldo played for hosts Portugal in <a href="/wiki/2019_UEFA_Nations_League_Finals" title="2019 UEFA Nations League Finals">the inaugural Nations League Finals</a> in June 2019. In the semi-finals on 5 June, he scored a hat-trick against <a href="/wiki/Switzerland_national_football_team" title="Switzerland national football team">Switzerland</a> to secure a spot in <a href="/wiki/2019_UEFA_Nations_League_Final" title="2019 UEFA Nations League Final">the final</a>. Upon netting the match's opening goal, he became the first player to score in 10 consecutive international competitions, breaking the record of nine he previously shared with Ghana's <a href="/wiki/Asamoah_Gyan" title="Asamoah Gyan">Asamoah Gyan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371">&#91;367&#93;</a></sup> In the final of the tournament four days later, Portugal defeated <a href="/wiki/Netherlands_national_football_team" title="Netherlands national football team">Netherlands</a> 1–0.<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">&#91;368&#93;</a></sup>
</p><p>On 10 September 2019, Ronaldo scored four goals in a 5–1 away win over <a href="/wiki/Lithuania_national_football_team" title="Lithuania national football team">Lithuania</a> in a <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2020_qualifying" title="UEFA Euro 2020 qualifying">Euro 2020 qualifying match</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">&#91;369&#93;</a></sup> in the process, he overtook Robbie Keane (23 goals) as the player with most goals in the <a href="/wiki/UEFA_European_Championship_qualifying" title="UEFA European Championship qualifying">UEFA European Championship qualifiers</a>, setting a new record with 25 goals.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">&#91;370&#93;</a></sup> On that occasion, Ronaldo also set a new record as the player who scored against the most national teams, 40,<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">&#91;371&#93;</a></sup> while also completing his eighth international hat-trick.<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">&#91;372&#93;</a></sup> On 14 October, he scored his 700th senior career goal for club and country from the penalty spot, in his 974th senior career appearance, a 2–1 away loss to <a href="/wiki/Ukraine_national_football_team" title="Ukraine national football team">Ukraine</a> in a Euro 2020 qualifier.<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">&#91;373&#93;</a></sup> On 17 November, Ronaldo scored his 99th international goal in a 2–0 win over Luxembourg, leading Portugal to qualify for <a href="/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2020" title="UEFA Euro 2020">Euro 2020</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378">&#91;374&#93;</a></sup> On 8 September 2020, Ronaldo scored his 100th and 101st international goals in a 2–0 away win over Sweden in a <a href="/wiki/2020%E2%80%9321_UEFA_Nations_League" title="2020–21 UEFA Nations League">2020–21 UEFA Nations League</a> match, becoming only the second male player ever, after <a href="/wiki/Ali_Daei" title="Ali Daei">Ali Daei</a> of Iran – and the first in Europe – to achieve this milestone.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">&#91;375&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">&#91;376&#93;</a></sup> On 13 October 2020, the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Football_Federation" title="Portuguese Football Federation">Portuguese Football Federation</a> announced that Ronaldo tested positive for <a href="/wiki/Coronavirus_disease_2019" class="mw-redirect" title="Coronavirus disease 2019">COVID-19</a> while being <a href="/wiki/Asymptomatic_carrier" title="Asymptomatic carrier">asymptomatic</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">&#91;377&#93;</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CR7COVIDMarca_382-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CR7COVIDMarca-382">&#91;378&#93;</a></sup> By 30 October, Ronaldo had recovered.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">&#91;379&#93;</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Player_profile">Player profile</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Style_of_play">Style of play</span></h3>
